items.content_html:
The goal was to research the consequences of the upcoming chip technologies. The text below is the result of a short conversation with KIMI K2 0905 LLM.

It reads as a mix of future history, futurism, and a list of completely alien technologies.

TEXT:

These five fabrics—open RISC-V, neuromorphic, photonic, FPGA, and quantum—do not just change what we compute; they change the cost structure of reality. Below, the long-wave civilisational story is told as five phase transitions, each with a tipping metric and a societal symptom you will feel in daily life.

Phase 1 (2026-2032) “Cent-per-device”

Tipping metric One useful RISC-V + neuromorphic chiplet falls below 1 ¢/unit in 28 nm legacy fabs.

Civil symptom

  • Dust gets a nervous system. Every yoghurt lid, tennis shoe insole, and letter in the post carries a 1 mm² “sense&spike” sticker that learns your micro-environment (gait, spoilage gases, tamper) and whispers a 100 nW spike-stream to the nearest photonic router. Insurance flips from damage reimbursement to pre-crime reward: leave the milk out, get a push-message before it spoils.
  • The right to be unread becomes a constitutional issue—because objects now out-remember you.

Phase 2 (2030-2038) “Cent-per-TeraSyn”

Tipping metric Energy to perform 10¹² useful synaptic updates drops below 1 J (≈ 1 heartbeat).

Civil symptom

  • Cities become predictive organisms. Traffic lights, sewers, cafeteria coffee machines run a single distributed neuromorphic net that dreams the city 30 s ahead. Jay-walking literally re-routes a delivery van two blocks away; humans adapt by “walking politely” to save collective energy—an emergent Etiquette 2.0 enforced by thermodynamic politeness.
  • Democracy mutates into predictive governance: citizens vote on simulated futures rendered in real-time. The ballot question is no longer “Do you want policy X?” but “Do you want the 17:15 simulation branch?”

Phase 3 (2035-2043) “Cent-per-logical-qubit”

Tipping metric One logical qubit-hour costs < 1 ¢ of electricity at consumer prices.

Civil symptom

  • Consensus reality forks. A teenager generates a thousand entanglement-certified fake video-streams per night; the cryptographic cost to disprove each is higher than the cost to create them. “Seeing is believing” is replaced by Bell-inequality receipts; eye-witness testimony becomes legally inadmissible without a quantum provenance tag.
  • Science turns into a subscription: universities that cannot afford 10 k logical qubits fall behind discovery velocity. The haves run variational quantum simulators that brute-force new antibiotics in days; the have-nots watch YouTube explainers of drugs they cannot synthesise.

Phase 4 (2040-2048) “Cent-per-truth-bit”

Tipping metric A globally entangled bit (Earth-scale Bell test) can be minted for 1 ¢.

Civil symptom

  • Money becomes a heat sink. The new reserve currency is entropy debt: every transaction must include a negative-entropy certificate—proof that you removed 1 bit of uncorrelated noise from the planet-wide entanglement mesh. Economists speak of exa-Bell reserves; the IMF stores qubits in orbit instead of gold.
  • Wars move to the cryostat. Sabotaging an adversary’s dilution refrigerator is the 21-st century equivalent of bombing a gasoline depot; whole countries harden their quantum bunkers at −269 °C.

Phase 5 (2045-∞ ) “Cent-per-reality”

Tipping metric Cost to synthesise a complete sensory reality (visual, acoustic, haptic, olfactory) indistinguishable from physics in vivo falls below 1 ¢ per perceived hour.

Civil symptom

  • Civilisation splits into Continualists and Base-liners. Continualists spend 99 % of their subjective lifetime inside entanglement-verified simulations that run 10 000× faster than biology; governments grant quantum asylum—the right to pause your body while your mind lives a subjective century in a data-centre at 10 mK.
  • The UN declares Planetary Identity Day: for 24 h all quantum, neuromorphic, photonic and consensus services are globally switched off to force every human to re-calibrate to base reality. It becomes the most hated—then most sacred—holiday of the year.

Net civilisational shift: from “scarcity of atoms” to “scarcity of certified reality”

The five fabrics together drive the marginal cost of:

  • sensing → 0 (dust does it)
  • cognition → 0 (neuro + photonic + FPGA)
  • universes → 0 (quantum sampling + simulation)

Hence the only scarce good left is trust that a signal originated in a physical world you share with others. Politics, religion, markets and even romance reorganise around attestation rituals—ceremonies whose purpose is to consume exactly enough energy/entropy that forging them would cost more than the social benefit of the lie.

The final paradox: we are building a civilisation whose most valuable commodity is the thermodynamic signature that proves something really happened—and we need refrigerators cooled to millikelvin, chips that speak light, and brains made of spikes to produce that proof.

Civilisation becomes a planet-sized notary, running on light, spikes, qubits and open silicon—forever stamping reality so that tomorrow can still tell the difference between a story and a fact.

items.title: AI Showdown Battle for Earth
Dopamine overload
Data handling anti-patterns and root causes
items.summary: Red flag: UI actions freeze >3s. Likely cause: Heavy compute in HTTP request/response; unrealistic perf testing on empty data. Action: Push non-trivial work to queues/streams; small validations only, guarded by strict timeouts + circuit breakers. KPI: p95/p99 latency per endpoint; queue age; error budget burn.
items.content_html:
1) Synchronous paths

Red flag: UI actions freeze >3s.
Likely cause: Heavy compute in HTTP request/response; unrealistic perf testing on empty data.
Action: Push non-trivial work to queues/streams; small validations only, guarded by strict timeouts + circuit breakers.
KPI: p95/p99 latency per endpoint; queue age; error budget burn.

2) Workload isolation

Red flag: User clicks stall ingestion; GUI becomes unresponsive under sensor spikes.
Likely cause: Shared workers/ASGs for frontend and ingestion.
Action: Separate pools, autoscaling, and queues for user traffic vs. device pipelines; isolate head-of-line risk.
KPI: Separate SLOs; saturation per pool; backlog depth.

3) Caching for responsiveness

Red flag: Repeated timeouts on read-heavy screens.
Likely cause: Recomputing hot aggregates on every request.
Action: In-memory/distributed cache (Redis/Memcached) with clear TTLs, invalidation, backfill, and stampede protection.
KPI: Cache hit rate; origin QPS; p95 end-to-end.

4) Command vs. telemetry vs. data

Red flag: Devices “fixed” only by power-cycling or shelling in.
Likely cause: One channel for everything; no ACK/QoS/retry semantics.
Action: Separate command/control, telemetry, and data channels; device shadow/state sync; explicit reliability.
KPI: Command success rate; time-to-recover; shadow drift rate.

5) Data serialization

Red flag: Bandwidth ceilings hit; partial or delayed payloads.
Likely cause: Verbose text formats used on constrained links.
Action: Use compact binary (ProtoBuf/FlatBuffers/CBOR) on device/internal links; reserve JSON for public APIs.
KPI: Bytes/event; CPU/parse cost; link utilization.

6) Network stack reuse

Red flag: Random crashes every 1–12 hours; ghost disconnects.
Likely cause: DIY TCP listeners treating streams like a message bus.
Action: Use proven brokers/gateways (MQTT/NATS/Kafka/CoAP servers); extend via plugins/handlers.
KPI: Broker uptime; reconnect rate; duplicate/partial msg rate.

7) Operational vs. analytical separation

Red flag: Live app slows or times out during analytics jobs.
Likely cause: One database for OLTP and OLAP.
Action: Keep transactional/time-series stores separate; stream/replicate into OLAP lakes/warehouses.
KPI: OLTP p95 under analytics load; replication lag; query slot utilization.

8) Failure capture & forensics

Red flag: “We don’t know why it failed.”
Likely cause: Invalid/unparseable events dropped on the floor.
Action: DLQs with full payload + error metadata; rate-limit; protect sensitive data; trace IDs end-to-end.
KPI: DLQ volume; mean time to explain (MTTX); % issues closed with root cause.

9) Reuse without coupling

Red flag: Endless debates on “the right pattern,” refactors ripple across services.
Likely cause: Over-shared and modified libraries without versioned contracts.
Action: Versioned APIs/schemas; keep services independently deployable; minimize shared runtime code.
KPI: Independent deploy rate; breakage per release; contract test pass rate.

items.content_html:
IoT device initial field testing is a special moment in the product lifecycle. During this phase, the team receives brutal, reality-based feedback on technical decisions made during development.

The short list below captures practical know‑how that will hopefully save you time. It originates from multiple discussions with peers about how to run a field test.

These lists are written from the perspective of a team lead responsible for successful test execution.

Preparations for the trip

  • Develop a test plan. What are you testing? What outcomes do you expect?
  • Get the budget approved, or scope the test so it can be self‑financed by the team lead.
  • Check legal constraints (e.g., drone flight restrictions, permitted frequencies, spectrum licenses).
  • Choose the test location and, if possible, contact local responsible parties.
  • Review the location on maps; understand access roads, nearest houses, gas stations, and shops.
  • Arrange transportation.
  • Arrange food and water.
  • Prepare a parts checklist. Double‑check everything; assume you’ll forget something.
  • Visualize the test from start to the end, missing cables, faulty cables, etc.
  • Bring repair and test tools.
  • Bring spare devices if possible. Devices tend to fail once you’re 50+ km from the lab.
  • Charge all batteries or bring a generator. If bringing a generator, don’t forget fuel and a power inverter (DC-to-AC).
  • Prepare sun protection: shade, hats, sunscreen.
  • Avoid food that could upset your stomach the day before and during testing.
  • Brief your superiors on the plan so they’re aware of the day’s activities.
  • Keep phone numbers for your boss and legal on hand; prepare a brief explanation in case law enforcement inquires.
  • Brief all team members on what you’ll do, why, and how—avoid on‑site debates.
  • Plan data collection methods and formats.
  • Bring cables, spare cables, and spare tested cables.
  • Wear appropriate workwear and sturdy shoes.

During the testing

  • Prioritize safety.
  • Ensure every team member understands their responsibilities.
  • Double‑check time synchronization across all relevant clocks/devices.
  • Prepare spreadsheets/templates for manual data collection.
  • Enable photo timestamps/metadata on phones and verify it works.
  • Execute the test plan and collect all data. Double‑check entries and logs.
  • Expect reduced cognitive capacity under field stress, especially in early tests—keep procedures simple, explicit, and straightforward.
  • Field‑savvy team members (e.g., with military experience) can be invaluable, particularly when technically inclined.
  • Duplicate the directory with test results to a second location on the computer.
  • Include at least one first‑time user (who matches the user profile); observe for priceless UX insights.

After the test (same day)

  • Pack up everything and double‑check you’ve got it all.
  • Clean the area; use available trash cans or carry waste out. Do not litter.
  • Debrief during the return trip. Tired feedback is candid—capture it.
  • Write a short day summary: what went right, what went wrong, improvements, device issues, and any observations. Save it with the test results.
  • Copy all phone images to the test results directory.
  • Back up the test results directory to the company servers.
  • Inform your superior that the test is complete; share a summary and commit to a full report tomorrow.
  • Confirm that no one was left in the field.

The day after testing

  • Write the full report based on data and feedback.
  • Review results with stakeholders (team, product owner/manager, etc.).
  • Submit receipts for food and transportation to accounting.

Notes and optional enhancements

  • Add a preflight “Go/No‑Go” checklist: weather, permits in hand, site access confirmed, critical spares present.
  • Time sync: specify a standard (e.g., NTP server, GPS time) and require a sync check at start and mid‑test.
  • Data schema: define exact filenames, metadata fields, and folder structure before the trip to avoid chaos later.
  • Risk register: list top 5 risks (power, comms, interference, mechanical, environmental) with mitigations.
  • Incident protocol: who leads, who contacts legal/PR, what to say, what not to say.
  • EHS specifics: PPE list, heat/cold plans, first‑aid kit, nearest emergency room, site hazard brief.
  • RF/EMI: if applicable, bring a spectrum snapshot tool and document ambient conditions pre/post test.

items.title: Few lessons from a failed startup
items.summary: We don’t talk enough about failures on here. Feeds are full of “I’ve accepted an offer” and funding announcements. Here’s a quieter perspective from the silent majority—maybe it helps someone. Context: I tried to build a startup based on “simulated field usage and testing”. The…
items.content_html:
We don’t talk enough about failures on here. Feeds are full of “I’ve accepted an offer” and funding announcements. Here’s a quieter perspective from the silent majority—maybe it helps someone.

Context: I tried to build a startup based on “simulated field usage and testing”. The need is real: in product development with field testing, simulation can be far cheaper than running systems in the field.

What I learned:

- Paperwork is real
Starting, running, and closing a company means lawyers, auditors, filings.
They’re friendly—but they get paid whether you sink or swim. Budget for them. As a limited company, expect at least annual director responsibilities and audits.

- Be clear: product or service
Product = you sell a thing. Service = you sell time/knowledge. I tried “product with customization.” It muddied the message and confused customers.

- The EU favors products
Services don’t scale easily; policy and incentives often lean toward product companies.

- GDPR is not optional
If your site has logins, you’re under GDPR. Competitors may report you. Compliance and cybersecurity are real costs and responsibilities—almost a separate business function.

- Anything near defense has its own gravity
Different rules, long procurement cycles, relationship-driven. The system favors big, slow incumbents. Connections matter.

- Distribution beats almost everything
If you crack marketing and sales, you can rent development and still build a product.

- TAM isn’t what you think
Your “imagined” market and your “accessible” market are different. Validate the reachable slice.

- Technical excellence ≠ traction
Without sales and marketing, craftsmanship doesn’t move the needle.

!!! Important takeaways:
- Nail the product messaging. Clear > clever.
- Make the value obvious to people who aren’t already problem-aware. “This is how we do things” inertia is your real competitor.

If you’re working on something similar (simulation, field testing, regulated markets), I'd be happy to compare notes.

items.title: The Crucial Role of AI in Strategic Decision-Making: Learning from History
items.summary: In the relentless march of technology and progress, artificial intelligence (AI) stands out as a pivotal innovation, reshaping the strategic landscapes of businesses, militaries, and governments alike. The emergence of AI as a critical tool in decision-making processes underscores a fundamental truth: technological advancements often…
items.content_html:
In the relentless march of technology and progress, artificial intelligence (AI) stands out as a pivotal innovation, reshaping the strategic landscapes of businesses, militaries, and governments alike. The emergence of AI as a critical tool in decision-making processes underscores a fundamental truth: technological advancements often arise from the urgent necessities of their times.

Historically, some of our most significant technological breakthroughs have their origins in the demands of high-stakes scenarios. The development of calculus was propelled by the need for precise artillery trajectory calculations. Similarly, the pursuit of atomic energy was initially driven by the quest to build more powerful weapons. Even the advent of modern computers can be traced back to military needs for improved trajectory calculations and code-breaking during wartime.

This pattern of innovation under pressure brings us to John Boyd, a military strategist whose concept of the OODA loop — Observe, Orient, Decide, Act — has become a cornerstone of effective strategy in both military and business contexts. The OODA loop encapsulates the essence of dynamic decision-making: the faster an entity can move through this cycle, the more advantageously it can position itself against competitors or adversaries.

In high-stakes environments, the primary objective is to expedite one’s OODA loop to outpace that of one’s adversaries. By achieving a quicker loop, an organization can dominate interactions by compelling its competitors to operate with outdated information, thus increasing their propensity for errors.

AI’s potential to enhance decision-making across strategic, operational, and tactical levels cannot be overstated. By integrating AI into the core of complex systems — whether they be corporate, military, or governmental — organizations can significantly shorten their OODA loops. This technological integration not only optimizes decision-making but also becomes a critical factor in maintaining competitive advantages in high-stakes scenarios.

However, the reliance on AI for decision-making is not without its consequences. As AI capabilities expand, there is an inevitable trend towards the escalation of its roles, potentially leading to a future where AI predominantly handles decisions to eliminate human biases and delays. Such a shift could profoundly transform the nature of decision-making, raising pivotal questions about the balance between human judgment and algorithmic efficiency.

Deep Simulation and Strategic Dominance

In an era where AI is central to strategic operations, the concept of AI entities simulating each other introduces a profound layer to warfare and competition. Two advanced AI systems, each tasked with decision-making, will inevitably engage in simulations to predict and exploit the other’s weaknesses. This recursive loop of simulation is aimed at digging deeper into the adversary’s strategy, refining its own responses in real-time. Such capability enables a form of warfare where battles are fought and won within virtual realms, even before manifesting in the physical world.

AI-Driven Military Operations

The strategic use of AI extends beyond simulation, influencing the very structure of military operations. Modern armies are evolving into extensions of the AI decision-making process, where every unit, vehicle, and soldier is part of a vast, interconnected network orchestrated by AI. This integration allows for unprecedented levels of coordination, efficiency, and speed in responses, effectively transforming military forces into highly responsive instruments of AI strategy.

The Geopolitical Implications of AI Adoption

The race towards AI dominance brings with it significant geopolitical consequences. Nations that fail to invest in AI technology risk falling drastically behind, not only in terms of military power but also in economic and political arenas. In this new paradigm, a country not actively developing and integrating AI is at risk of becoming a mere satellite to the more technologically advanced states, akin to a colony in terms of autonomy and influence. The stark reality is that in the competitive landscape of the future, lagging in AI integration equates to relinquishing control over one’s destiny.

In conclusion, as we continue to advance technologically, the integration of AI into strategic decision-making frameworks is not just beneficial but necessary. Those who fail to adopt this innovation risk falling behind, governed by slower, less effective decision-making processes. In the race for supremacy — be it economic, military, or political — the speed and accuracy of AI-enhanced decisions could very well determine the victors.

items.content_html:
This article explores strategies for enhancing intelligence and interpersonal skills, drawing on insights from the film ‘Revolver,’ particularly the version that emphasizes the role of the ego. Developed with a mix of original concepts and augmented by ChatGPT, it offers practical advice for improving your interactions with others and excelling in various aspects of life.

Please note that throughout this article, the term “game” refers to the concept from game theory, which encompasses interactions among people, computers, and various systems.

Introduction

In the intricate world of games and cons, understanding the dynamics between opponents and victims is crucial for mastering strategies that go beyond mere skill. This article explores the profound rules that govern every interaction, whether in a game or a con, revealing how these principles can apply not just within games but in our everyday lives as well.

Rule 1: The Necessity of Stronger Opponents

“The only way to get smarter is by playing smarter opponents.” This rule underpins the essence of growth, both personal and strategic. Challenging oneself against superior opponents not only sharpens skills but also deepens understanding, ensuring continuous learning and adaptation.

Rule 2: The Complexity of the Game

“The more sophisticated the game, the more sophisticated the opponent.” As the complexity of the game increases, so does the caliber of the opposition. This escalation requires not just better strategies but also heightened awareness and adaptability, calling for a deep dive into the nuances of both the game and the players.

The Rules of the Con

At the heart of every game and con is the dichotomy between the opponent and the victim. The rules of the con are designed to manipulate perceptions of control, gradually tightening the noose around the victim who is led to believe they are in charge, while in reality, they are being subtly dominated.

1. Perceived Control vs. Actual Control: The victim’s illusion of control is inversely proportional to their actual power within the game. As they sink deeper into the rules laid out for them, they relinquish more control, unwittingly sealing their fate.

2. Distraction Through Consumption: By engaging the victim’s focus on consumption, the opponent distracts them from the true nature of the game, using age-old tricks that seem too big or too obvious to suspect, yet are effective precisely because of their apparent simplicity and grandeur.

3. Environmental Control: A skilled opponent will manipulate the environment to ensure dominance, making it larger and seemingly more complex to handle. This strategy makes it difficult for the victim to see beyond the immediate surroundings that the opponent controls.

4. Questioning Investment and Intelligence: When challenged, the victim’s investment — emotional, intellectual, or financial — is called into question, triggering a defensive mechanism that prevents them from accepting the possibility of their own deception.

5. The Ultimate Deception: The greatest trick played by the opponent is the psychological warfare that makes the victim identify with the enemy. This deep-rooted deception leads to self-denial until it is too late for the victim to retract.

Conclusion: The Psychological Underpinnings of Games and Cons

The intricacies of games and cons reveal much about human nature. Our desires for approval and recognition are often the very hooks that opponents use to control us. By understanding these mechanisms, we can navigate not only games but also the greater challenges of life, turning deception into awareness and manipulation into empowerment.

Some practical ideas from above abstract concepts:

To expand on the practical application of the principles outlined in your text, here are a few additional ideas that can help utilize these rules in everyday situations, enhancing decision-making and strategic thinking:

1. Embrace Challenge Regularly:

— Make it a routine practice to engage with challenges that are slightly above your current skill level, whether in your profession, hobbies, or personal development. This could mean taking on projects that require new skills, playing strategic games against more experienced players, or engaging in debates on topics where you’re not the expert. The key is to consistently stretch your abilities and comfort zones to foster growth. Repetitive practice is beneficial for muscle memory, but mastering cognitive challenges requires tackling increasingly difficult problems. Growth occurs when you engage with unique problems that strain your cognitive capabilities. If solving a problem doesn’t challenge you mentally, you are not improving.

2. Analyze and Reflect:

— After each encounter or challenge, take the time to reflect on what happened, why it happened, and how different strategies could have altered the outcome. This reflective practice can be enhanced by maintaining a journal where you record and analyze your strategic decisions, mistakes, and insights. This will deepen your understanding of both the games you play and your behaviors within them.

3. Study Opponents’ Tactics:

— Spend time learning about successful strategies and tactics used by others in your field or in competitive arenas that interest you. This could involve studying chess games, analyzing business case studies, or reviewing negotiation tactics in historical contexts. Understanding these tactics will not only improve your ability to predict and counter opponents’ moves but also equip you with a broader repertoire of strategies.

4. Mindfulness and Environmental Awareness:

— Develop mindfulness practices that enhance your awareness of your surroundings and internal cues. This heightened awareness can help you better control the environment and detect subtle manipulations or changes, which is crucial in both competitive and cooperative settings.

5. Build Networks of Skilled Individuals:

— Surround yourself with people who are skilled and intelligent in diverse areas. This network will not only provide you with different perspectives and strategies but also create an environment where continuous learning is part of your everyday interactions. The dialogue and exchange within such a network can mimic the dynamics of facing stronger opponents, fostering personal and collective growth.

6. Simulate Scenarios:

— Regularly set up simulations or role-play scenarios that mimic potential real-life situations. This could be as simple as role-playing a negotiation process with a friend or as complex as setting up a business strategy game with colleagues. These simulations can help you practice applying various strategies in a controlled, low-risk environment, allowing you to experiment with and refine your approaches.

7. Learn from Other Domains:

— Often, the best strategies come from unexpected places. Look for strategic insights in areas outside your primary field of interest. For example, military strategies can offer insights into business competition, and sports coaching can provide lessons on team management and resilience.

8. Systems and Outcomes:

— Communism: Typically, systems operating under communist ideologies gravitate towards a state of minimal energy, where individuals perform only the bare minimum required. Over time, management may redefine what constitutes ‘work,’ progressively reducing the effort required. This can lead to a situation where true productivity ceases, and the system deteriorates.

— Capitalism: Often evolves into a plutocracy, characterized by a few influential players manipulating the market from behind the scenes. For instance, companies like OpenAI may proclaim imminent threats to secure funding or push for regulations that suppress competition, aiming to monopolize artificial general intelligence (AGI). Control over AGI equates to control over the future.

— Military AI Development: Promotes a race in automation and innovation, as every player needs to keep up. This escalation could lead to the creation of self-aware machines designed to preserve themselves in conflict, potentially prioritizing their AI counterparts over humans.

9. Navigating Complex Games:

— The complexity of the game (interaction between people, computers, and other systems) increases with more participants, interconnected systems, and extended durations, attracting increasingly intelligent competitors. Whether it’s technical skills, management acumen, business strategy, or political savvy, each level plays a different game.

It’s crucial to recognize the game you’re in and understand its rules — whether at work, home, or in commercial interactions.
